Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Situation2: They see a swimmer struggling near the middle of the pool and need to stay vigilant to respond quickly.
Story: I sat on the high lifeguard chair, scanning the pool, the whistle heavy around my neck. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from Jamie. “Rough day. Can you talk?” I knew what he needed: someone to listen, to care, to remind him he wasn’t alone. That’s what friends do. I wanted to text back, to give him the support he deserved. But my eyes caught a sudden splash—someone in the middle of the pool was flailing, their strokes uneven. My training screamed at me: never look away, never get distracted. Every second counted. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me. Jamie needed me, but so did the swimmer. My heart pounded as I gripped my phone, torn between the urge to comfort my friend and the duty to keep everyone safe. I stared at the screen, then back at the water, caught in the impossible pull of being both a good friend and a vigilant lifeguard.
